template.name: AWS_Guidance for Generative AI Deployments using Amazon SageMaker JumpStart
template.desc:
Guidance for Generative AI Deployments using Amazon SageMaker JumpStart


This Guidance demonstrates how to deploy a generative artificial intelligence (AI) model provided by Amazon SageMaker JumpStart to create an asynchronous SageMaker endpoint with the ease of the AWS Cloud Development Kit (AWS CDK). AWS CDK pipelines will create an asynchronous Amazon SageMaker endpoint and leverage the respective model to help accelerate and simplify the development process with preconfigured components that you can use to develop your applications. This Guidance uses the Stable Diffusion foundation model (FM) as an example, however, you can replace this model with any other model available on Amazon SageMaker JumpStart.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-477
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-477: Use of Obsolete Function The code uses deprecated or obsolete functions, which suggests that the code has not been actively reviewed or maintained.

weakness.name: CWE-703
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-703: Improper Check or Handling of Exceptional Conditions The product does not properly anticipate or handle exceptional conditions that rarely occur during normal operation of the product.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure communication
countermeasure.desc:
Enforce HTTPS:

  • Configure your server to serve content exclusively over HTTPS, redirecting all HTTP requests to HTTPS. This ensures data is encrypted during transit.
  • Utilize HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) to instruct browsers to only communicate with the server using secure HTTPS connections.

Validate SSL/TLS Certificates:

  • Ensure your server uses a valid SSL/TLS certificate from a reputable Certificate Authority (CA). This confirms the server's identity to clients.
  • Implement certificate pinning in your client-side application to only trust certificates matching a specific hash. This protects against MITM attacks using fraudulent certificates.

Secure TLS Configuration:

  • Use strong ciphers: Configure your server to use strong encryption ciphers and protocols. Avoid deprecated protocols like SSLv3 and weak ciphers.
  • Regularly update your server's TLS configuration based on the latest security standards and recommendations, such as those provided by the SSL Labs' SSL Test or Mozilla's SSL Configuration Generator.

Fallback Scenarios:

  • Implement logic to handle secure fallback scenarios. If a secure connection cannot be established, do not fallback to insecure protocols or encryption standards.
  • Provide clear messaging to the user when a secure connection cannot be established, advising them of potential security risks.

countermeasure.name: Ensure the application does not use unsupported, insecure, or deprecated client-side technologies
countermeasure.desc:
1. Inventory Current Technologies

  • Identify all client-side technologies currently in use within your application. This can be done through code reviews, automated scanning tools, and developer interviews.
  • Create a documented inventory that includes versions and dependencies to keep track of what technologies are used and where.

2. Assess and Prioritize

  • Evaluate the necessity of each technology identified in your inventory, focusing on those known to be deprecated or insecure, such as NSAPI plugins, Flash, Shockwave, ActiveX, Silverlight, NACL, and client-side Java applets.
  • Prioritize the removal or replacement of these technologies based on the level of security risk they pose to your application.

3. Seek Modern Alternatives

  • Research modern, secure alternatives that provide similar functionality without the security risks. For instance, consider using HTML5, CSS3, and JavaScript APIs as replacements for Flash and Silverlight.
  • Test alternatives for compatibility, functionality, and performance to ensure they meet your application's requirements.

4. Implement Replacement Technologies

  • Develop a migration plan that outlines steps to replace deprecated technologies with chosen alternatives. This plan should include timelines, testing phases, and rollback procedures.
  • Refactor and test your application with the new technologies. Ensure comprehensive testing is done to prevent functionality loss or new vulnerabilities.

5. Update Security Policies

  • Revise your security policies and development guidelines to prohibit the use of known insecure or deprecated technologies.
  • Educate your development team about these policies and the reasons behind them, emphasizing the importance of security and modernization.

6. Monitor and Review

  • Stay informed about the security status of client-side technologies by subscribing to security bulletins and using automated tools to monitor your applications dependencies.
  • Regularly review and update your applications technology inventory to catch any use of deprecated technologies early.

7. Continuous Integration and Deployment (CI/CD) Pipeline Integration

  • Integrate security checks into your CI/CD pipeline to automatically detect the use of deprecated or insecure technologies.
  • Use tools that can flag the introduction of banned technologies during the development phase, preventing them from being deployed.

reference.name: Testing Information Gathering

countermeasure.name: Implement custom error handling on the client side
countermeasure.desc:
Design Custom Error Messages:

  • Develop a set of custom error messages that are informative and user-friendly, avoiding technical language that could confuse users or reveal system internals.
  • Ensure messages are generic enough to prevent information leakage but specific enough to be helpful. For instance, rather than saying "Invalid input in field", use "Please check your entry and try again."

Categorize Errors:

  • Classify errors based on their nature and impact. Different categories might include validation errors, network issues, or system failures. This classification helps in delivering the most appropriate message to the user.

Implement Error Handling Mechanisms:

  • Use try-catch blocks and event listeners (for unhandled exceptions and promise rejections) to capture errors. Frameworks and libraries often offer built-in mechanisms or best practices for error handlingutilize these fully.

Secure Error Logging:

  • Log detailed error information to a secure, server-side endpoint for analysis. Ensure that this data is sanitized to remove any sensitive user information before logging.
  • Use secure transmission methods (e.g., HTTPS) for sending error logs to prevent interception.

Feedback Mechanism for Users:

  • Provide users with an immediate acknowledgment of the error, reassuring them that the issue is recognized. Include guidance or next steps when possible, such as contacting support with a unique error code.

Dynamic Error Response:

  • Adapt the error handling response based on the application state or user context. For instance, errors during a checkout process might prompt different messaging or options compared to errors encountered during browsing.

Review and Update Error Handling Regularly:

  • Periodically review error messages, logging mechanisms, and handling strategies to ensure they align with current best practices, user feedback, and evolving security threats.
  • Stay informed about new security vulnerabilities and update error handling mechanisms as needed to address these risks.

Training and Documentation:

  • Educate development and QA teams on the importance of secure and user-friendly error handling. Provide documentation on how to implement and test custom error handling within the application.

countermeasure.name: Safeguard sensitive information stored on the client side
countermeasure.desc:
1. Minimize Client-Side Storage of Sensitive Data

  • Avoid storing sensitive data (e.g., passwords, personal identification information, credit card numbers) on the client side whenever possible. If the information doesn't need to be on the client, don't store it there.

2. Use Secure Storage Mechanisms

  • For essential data that must be stored client-side, use secure storage options like Web Cryptography API for encryption before storage.
  • Utilize HTTPS to protect the integrity and confidentiality of data in transit between the client and server.

3. Apply Encryption

  • Encrypt sensitive information using strong encryption algorithms (e.g., AES) before storing it client-side.
  • Store encryption keys securely, preferably not on the client side. If they must be on the client, use secure storage like the device's keychain or keystore.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to data or services by accessing a client-side secret
threat.desc:
This threat typically revolves around the exposure or improper handling of sensitive information stored or processed on the client side of an application. This sensitive information can include API keys, credentials, tokens, or any other form of secret that, when obtained by an unauthorized entity, could lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, or even the complete takeover of user accounts or services. The vulnerability often arises due to inadequate security measures in the application's design, such as storing secrets in easily accessible locations or transmitting them without proper encryption.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Attackers can range from curious individuals with minimal technical skills who stumble upon the secret through trial and error or by leveraging basic tools, to sophisticated hackers using advanced techniques and automated scripts to extract secrets from client-side resources.
  • Attack Vectors: Common vectors include:
    • Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): Malicious scripts injected into web pages that extract client-side secrets.
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Intercepting communications between the client and server to capture unencrypted or poorly secured secrets.
    • Reverse Engineering: Decompiling or analyzing client-side applications (e.g., mobile or desktop apps) to extract hardcoded secrets.
    • Social Engineering: Tricking users into revealing secrets through phishing or other deceptive methods.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to private, sensitive, or confidential information.
  • Financial Loss: Direct financial loss from unauthorized transactions, or indirect costs associated with incident response and mitigation.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from users or clients, potentially leading to a decrease in user base or business opportunities.
  • Legal and Compliance Issues: Violations of data protection regulations (e.g., GDPR, CCPA) can result in hefty fines and legal repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker discovers an API key hardcoded within the JavaScript code of a web application. Using this API key, the attacker is able to access the application's backend services without any authorization, leading to data leakage.
  • Scenario 2: Through a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability, an attacker injects a malicious script into a web page that is executed by the browser of any user visiting the page. This script is designed to send any stored cookies or tokens, which might include session tokens or other secrets, back to the attacker, allowing them to impersonate the user.
  • Scenario 3: A mobile application developer includes a third-party service's secret key directly within the app's codebase. Upon reverse engineering the application, an attacker finds this key and uses it to generate unauthorized requests to the third-party service, incurring costs or accessing restricted data.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the application by the use of deprecated client-side technologies
threat.desc:
Deprecated technologies often have known vulnerabilities that are no longer patched or supported by their developers. Attackers exploit these vulnerabilities to bypass security measures, inject malicious code, or steal sensitive information. This risk is heightened when applications continue to rely on outdated libraries, frameworks, plugins, or protocols, exposing them to a range of attacks that could compromise the application and its data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Include both opportunistic hackers looking for easy targets by scanning the internet for vulnerable applications, and targeted attackers who specifically aim to compromise an application or organization by exploiting known vulnerabilities in deprecated technologies.
  • Attack Vectors: Common vectors include:
    • Exploiting known vulnerabilities: Using existing exploits against known vulnerabilities in outdated client-side software.
    • Injection attacks: Executing malicious scripts or SQL commands through vulnerabilities in old technologies.
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks: Intercepting unsecured or weakly encrypted traffic to steal data or inject malicious payloads.
    • Phishing and social engineering: Tricking users into executing malicious actions or revealing sensitive information through compromised or malicious versions of deprecated components.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers may gain unauthorized access to the application, allowing them to access or modify sensitive information.
  • Data Breach: Exposure of personal, financial, or proprietary data can result from successful attacks.
  • System Compromise: Attackers can leverage vulnerabilities to gain control over the application or underlying systems.
  • Loss of Reputation: Users' loss of trust in the application or organization due to perceived negligence in maintaining security standards.
  • Legal and Compliance Penalties: Non-compliance with security standards and regulations can lead to legal action and fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker discovers that a web application is using an outdated JavaScript library known to have a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability. The attacker crafts a URL with a malicious script and convinces a user to click on it. The script executes within the user's browser, stealing their session token and giving the attacker unauthorized access to the user's account.
  • Scenario 2: A mobile application built with a deprecated version of a web-view component is found to improperly handle SSL certificate validation. An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on users connected to a compromised network, intercepting and decrypting traffic between the users and the application to steal credentials and personal information.
  • Scenario 3: A desktop application relies on an outdated cryptographic library for encrypting user data. Researchers disclose a vulnerability in the library that allows attackers to decrypt sensitive data without the encryption key. An attacker exploits this vulnerability by distributing malware that targets users of the application, leading to a data breach.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Adversaries may sniff network traffic to capture information about an environment
threat.desc:
Network traffic sniffing involves adversaries capturing packets of data as they travel across a network. The goal is to extract information that can be used for malicious purposes. This activity is particularly threatening in unsecured or poorly secured networks, where data often travels unencrypted. Attackers can gather a wide range of sensitive information, including login credentials, personal information, internal communications, and proprietary data. Traffic sniffing can be passive, where the attacker silently captures data without altering or disrupting the flow, or active, involving injecting malicious packets into the network to generate more traffic to capture.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: These range from individual hackers and hobbyists looking for vulnerabilities to exploit for personal gain, to organized crime groups and state-sponsored actors targeting specific organizations for espionage or financial theft.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unsecured Wireless Networks: Public Wi-Fi networks are particularly susceptible to sniffing attacks. Attackers can capture traffic of users connected to these networks.
    • ARP Spoofing: Attackers send forged ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) messages over a local area network to link their MAC address with the IP address of a legitimate computer or server in the network, causing any traffic meant for that IP address to be sent to the attacker instead.
    • Port Mirroring: This is often a legitimate network monitoring tool that can be maliciously configured to send copies of network packets to an attacker.
    • Installing Network Monitoring Software: Attackers might gain physical or remote access to install packet-capturing tools on network devices.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive or proprietary information.
  • Credential Theft: Capturing usernames, passwords, and session tokens that can be used for unauthorized access to systems and accounts.
  • Surveillance and Espionage: Monitoring and recording communications for future attacks or for intelligence gathering.
  • Network Disruption: In active sniffing scenarios, attackers can disrupt or manipulate network traffic, leading to denial of service or targeted attacks against individuals or systems.
  • Loss of Trust: Damaged reputation among users, clients, and partners due to perceived negligence in securing network traffic.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: In an unencrypted Wi-Fi network at a coffee shop, an attacker uses a simple packet sniffer to capture data packets. They extract login credentials of several users accessing their email and social media accounts over the network.
  • Scenario 2: Within an organization, an attacker performs ARP spoofing to redirect traffic through their device. This allows them to capture sensitive documents being transmitted between departments, including financial reports and personal employee information.
  • Scenario 3: An attacker gains physical access to a corporate network and installs a network monitoring tool on a switch using port mirroring. This setup sends a copy of all network traffic to the attacker, who later analyzes it to extract intellectual property and confidential communications.

threat.name: An attacker can leverage client-side error-handling weaknesses to disclose sensitive or confidential information
threat.desc:
Client-side error handling refers to the mechanisms in place within a client application (such as web browsers, mobile apps, or desktop applications) to manage and respond to errors that occur during the application's operation. When error handling is implemented poorly, it can lead to the unintended disclosure of sensitive or confidential information. Attackers can exploit these weaknesses to extract data that can help them in further attacks, such as system details, user information, or application logic.

Insecure error handling on the client side often manifests through verbose error messages that include stack traces, database queries, internal system paths, or cryptographic keys. These messages are intended for debugging purposes but can become a security vulnerability when exposed in a production environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: This can range from amateur hackers who stumble upon the error messages while using the application in unintended ways, to sophisticated attackers who deliberately induce errors in client applications to gather information.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Inducing Errors: By supplying unexpected inputs or malformed data, attackers can trigger error conditions in client-side applications.
    • Intercepting Traffic: Attackers can intercept network traffic between the client and server to capture error messages transmitted in plain text.
    • Inspecting Client-Side Code: By examining the client-side code (e.g., JavaScript in web applications), attackers can identify error handling routines that leak information.

Impacts

  • Information Disclosure: Exposure of sensitive data, such as system paths, database schema, or credentials, which can be used for more targeted attacks.
  • Privacy Violation: Personal user information may be revealed through error messages, violating privacy laws and regulations.
  • System Compromise: Detailed error information can assist attackers in exploiting other vulnerabilities within the system, leading to a full system compromise.
  • Loss of Reputation: Users and stakeholders may lose trust in an application or organization if they perceive it to be insecure or poorly developed.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker inputs unexpected characters into a web form, causing the application to throw a detailed error message that includes the SQL query used. This information is used to craft a SQL injection attack.
  • Scenario 2: A mobile application crashes when a certain type of data is input. The error report generated and displayed to the user includes the applications directory structure and API keys. An attacker convinces a user to share a screenshot of this crash report under the guise of helping with the problem.
  • Scenario 3: A desktop application fails to handle a file input correctly, displaying an error message that reveals the path of the file it attempted to access. An attacker uses this information to understand the application's file access patterns and develops a privilege escalation exploit.

weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-541
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-541: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in an Include File If an include file source is accessible, the file can contain usernames and passwords, as well as sensitive information pertaining to the application and system.

countermeasure.name: Disable direct internet and root access for notebook
countermeasure.desc:
Disable direct internet access and root access for AWS SageMaker notebook instances to ensure secure and restricted access.

  1. Disable Direct Internet Access:
    • Set DirectInternetAccess to Disabled when creating or updating notebook instances.
  2. Disable Root Access:
    • Configure IAM policies or lifecycle configurations to restrict root access.
  3. Enable VPC-Only Mode:
    • Specify VPC subnets and security groups to route all traffic through your VPC.

reference.name: Configure security in Amazon SageMaker

countermeasure.name: Enable inter-container traffic encryption for distributed training jobs
countermeasure.desc:
Enable inter-container traffic encryption for distributed training jobs in AWS SageMaker to protect data during transfer between containers.

Enable Traffic Encryption:

  • Set the InterContainerTrafficEncryption parameter to True when creating or updating distributed training jobs. This ensures that all data transferred between containers is encrypted.

Verify Encryption Configuration:

  • Ensure that all containers in the distributed training job are configured to support encrypted communication.
  • Regularly review and audit the encryption settings to maintain compliance and security standards.

countermeasure.name: Enable network isolation for training jobs
countermeasure.desc:
Configure network isolation (VPC) for SageMaker training jobs to ensure containers cannot access the internet or other network resources without permission.

Enable Network Isolation:

  • Set the EnableNetworkIsolation parameter to True when creating or updating training jobs. This prevents containers from accessing the internet and other network resources.

Specify VPC Configuration:

  • Define VPC subnets and security groups to control network access for the training jobs.
  • Ensure the security groups are configured to allow only necessary inbound and outbound traffic.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Uncontrolled notebook instance access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Uncontrolled notebook instance access refers to improperly configured SageMaker notebook instances that allow unrestricted access, leading to security risks such as unauthorized data access and misuse of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • Malicious insiders
    • External attackers
    • Negligent users
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Enabled direct internet access
    • Allowed root access
    • Misconfigured security groups and ACLs
    • Exploitation of software vulnerabilities

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized access to sensitive data
  • Integrity: Data and model tampering
  • Availability: Service disruption or resource misuse
  • Reputation: Damage from data breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unrestricted Internet Access:
    • An attacker exploits software vulnerabilities on a notebook instance with internet access, exfiltrating sensitive data.
  2. Root Access Misuse:
    • A user with root access installs malicious software, compromising the notebook instance.
  3. Misconfigured Network Controls:
    • An attacker gains access through open ports on a misconfigured instance, stealing and manipulating data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATLAS - AML.T0044 - Full AI Model Access

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate network isolation occurs when Amazon SageMaker resources, such as training jobs, endpoints, or notebook instances, are not properly segregated within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). This can lead to unauthorized access, data leakage, and potential security breaches, as these resources might be accessible from untrusted networks or the internet.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers (hackers)
    • Malicious insiders
    • Negligent users
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Lack of VPC configuration for SageMaker resources
    • Misconfigured VPC security groups and network ACLs
    • Public IP addresses assigned to instances
    • Insufficiently restricted endpoint access

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data due to unauthorized network access
  • Integrity: Data manipulation or tampering through unsecured network channels
  • Availability: Service disruptions from unauthorized network traffic or denial of service attacks
  • Reputation: Organizational damage due to data breaches and security incidents

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Publicly Accessible Endpoints: A SageMaker endpoint is configured without VPC isolation and is accessible from the internet. An attacker discovers the endpoint and exploits vulnerabilities to access sensitive data and models.
  • Misconfigured Security Groups: Training jobs are launched without proper security group restrictions, allowing unauthorized network access from other instances within the VPC or even from the internet.
  • Lack of Network Isolation: SageMaker notebook instances are deployed without VPC configurations, exposing them to public networks. An attacker intercepts the network traffic and exfiltrates sensitive information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1021 - Remote Services||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unencrypted inter-container communication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unencrypted inter-container communication refers to the transmission of data between containers in a SageMaker environment without encryption. This can expose sensitive information to interception and unauthorized access, especially in distributed training scenarios where data is frequently exchanged between multiple containers.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents:
    • External attackers (hackers)
    • Malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Network eavesdropping on inter-container traffic
    • Exploitation of network vulnerabilities to intercept data
    • Lack of encryption mechanisms in the container communication setup

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data such as model parameters, training data, and other proprietary information
  • Integrity: Risk of data tampering during transmission, leading to corrupted models or inaccurate results
  • Compliance: Non-compliance with data protection regulations requiring encryption of sensitive data in transit
  • Reputation: Damage to organizational trust and reputation due to data breaches

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Network Eavesdropping: An attacker gains access to the network segment where SageMaker containers are communicating. Without encryption, the attacker can intercept and read sensitive data being transmitted between containers.
  • Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker inserts themselves between communicating containers in a distributed training job, intercepting and potentially altering the data being exchanged. This compromises the integrity of the training process and the resulting model.
  • Internal Threat: A malicious insider with network access to the SageMaker environment can capture unencrypted traffic between containers, gaining access to sensitive information and potentially leaking it.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1040 - Network Sniffing||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-342
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-342: Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values An exact value or random number can be precisely predicted by observing previous values.

countermeasure.name: Aggregate security findings from AWS services for centralized management
countermeasure.desc: Enable AWS Security Hub to automatically aggregate and consolidate security findings from integrated services such as GuardDuty, Inspector, and Macie. This centralization provides a unified view of security across your AWS environment, improving visibility and simplifying incident response. Ensure proper configuration and integration of these services with Security Hub, and regularly review aggregated findings to promptly address vulnerabilities. Centralized management enhances security oversight and reduces the time required to identify and resolve security issues.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Inadequate resilience to disruptions
threat.desc:
General threat description
AWS Security Hub may face service degradation or outages if resources are deployed in a single region, limiting availability during regional disruptions.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Natural disasters, network failures, or targeted cyberattacks can cause regional outages that impact availability if services are not distributed across regions.

Impacts
Reduced visibility into security posture, delayed incident detection, and compromised security monitoring.

Example Attack Scenarios
A regional outage affects the availability of Security Hub, causing delayed responses to critical security events and gaps in compliance monitoring.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Non-compliance with security standards
threat.desc:
General threat description
AWS Security Hub can fail to adhere to security frameworks and regulations, resulting in missed critical security vulnerabilities and legal penalties.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Misconfigured or unmonitored AWS services, failure to enable security controls, or outdated configurations can lead to non-compliance with security standards like CIS, PCI-DSS, or GDPR.

Impacts
Reputational damage, financial penalties, and increased vulnerability to attacks due to missed compliance benchmarks.

Example Attack Scenarios
A company using AWS Security Hub fails to configure required security standards, missing critical vulnerabilities that lead to a data breach, and regulatory penalties.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unaggregated security findings
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without aggregation of security findings, incidents from multiple sources may be overlooked, delaying responses and leaving the system vulnerable.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Disjointed security systems, poor integration of AWS services like GuardDuty, Inspector, or Macie, and failure to centralize security event data.

Impacts
Delayed incident response, increased risk of undetected vulnerabilities, and difficulty in maintaining a unified security posture.

Example Attack Scenarios
Security findings from GuardDuty and Macie are not consolidated in Security Hub, leading to missed alerts about a data exfiltration incident.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1213 - Data from Information Repositories

threat.name: Non-compliance with security standards
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failure to meet required security standards and frameworks in AWS Security Hub can lead to security gaps and regulatory breaches.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Neglecting to configure compliance checks, ignoring security findings, or improper resource setup can result in non-compliance with standards like PCI-DSS or CIS.

Impacts
Financial penalties, legal consequences, security vulnerabilities, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios
An organization fails to enable Security Hub compliance checks, missing critical configuration flaws, leading to a security breach and fines for violating industry standards like GDPR.

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-1037
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1037: Processor Optimization Removal or Modification of Security-critical Code The developer builds a security-critical protection mechanism into the software, but the processor optimizes the execution of the program such that the mechanism is removed or modified.

weakness.name: CWE-342
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-342: Predictable Exact Value from Previous Values An exact value or random number can be precisely predicted by observing previous values.

countermeasure.name: Aggregate security findings from AWS services for centralized management
countermeasure.desc: Enable AWS Security Hub to automatically aggregate and consolidate security findings from integrated services such as GuardDuty, Inspector, and Macie. This centralization provides a unified view of security across your AWS environment, improving visibility and simplifying incident response. Ensure proper configuration and integration of these services with Security Hub, and regularly review aggregated findings to promptly address vulnerabilities. Centralized management enhances security oversight and reduces the time required to identify and resolve security issues.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-614
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-614: Sensitive Cookie in HTTPS Session Without 'Secure' Attribute The Secure attribute for sensitive cookies in HTTPS sessions is not set, which could cause the user agent to send those cookies in plaintext over an HTTP session.

countermeasure.name: Secure AWS Amplify environment variables
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the secure management of environment variables within AWS Amplify, follow these best practices:

  1. Encryption of Sensitive Data: Ensure that sensitive information, such as API keys, passwords, and secrets, are encrypted. AWS Amplify supports environment variable encryption by default when stored. For more details, refer to the official AWS documentation on environment variables.
  2. Least Privilege Principle: Limit access to environment variables to only those users and applications that require it. This mitigates the risk of unauthorized access. AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) roles and policies should be properly configured to enforce the principle of least privilege. Refer to IAM Best Practices for detailed guidance.
  3. Regularly Review and Rotate Credentials: Implement a routine for periodically reviewing environment variables and rotating credentials to minimize the risk of credential leakage or misuse. This is an essential part of maintaining a secure environment and can help in mitigating risks proactively.
  4. Use Parameter Store or Secrets Manager: To enhance security, consider using AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or AWS Secrets Manager to manage environment variables. These services provide additional security controls like automatic rotation, audit logs, and fine-grained access control. Detailed information can be found in the respective Parameter Store and Secrets Manager documentation.
  5. Monitor and Audit Environment Variables Usage: Implement monitoring and logging to track the access and modification of environment variables. AWS CloudTrail and Amazon CloudWatch can be utilized for this purpose, providing a comprehensive audit trail and alerting capabilities. Refer to the CloudTrail User Guide and CloudWatch Documentation for further insights.

By adhering to these best practices and leveraging the relevant AWS services, cloud engineers can securely manage environment variables in AWS Amplify, significantly reducing the risk of exposure and unauthorized access to sensitive information.

For more comprehensive security best practices in AWS Amplify, refer to the official AWS Amplify Security Best Practices.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Use __Host- prefix for cookies in Amplify default domain
countermeasure.desc:
When you use Amplify to deploy a web app, Amplify hosts it for you on the default amplifyapp.com domain. You can view your app on a URL formatted as https://branch-name.d1m7bkiki6tdw1.amplifyapp.com.

To augment the security of your Amplify applications, the amplifyapp.com domain is registered in the Public Suffix List (PSL). For further security, we recommend that you use cookies with a __Host- prefix if you ever need to set sensitive cookies in the default domain name for your Amplify applications. This practice will help to defend your domain against cross-site request forgery attempts (CSRF). For more information see the Set-Cookie page in the Mozilla Developer Network.

For more detailed information, refer to the official AWS Amplify security best practices documentation: AWS Amplify Security Best Practices

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Cross-site request forgery attempts (CSRF)
threat.desc:
General threat description
CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) attacks exploit the trust that a web application has in a user's browser by tricking the user into executing unwanted actions on a different website where they are authenticated, without their knowledge or consent.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers leverage social engineering techniques, such as sending a malicious link via email or embedding it in a trusted website, to persuade users to click on it while they are authenticated on the target website.
Impacts
Successful CSRF attacks can result in unauthorized actions on behalf of unsuspecting users, potentially compromising user data, performing unauthorized transactions, or changing account settings.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sends an email with a malicious link to a user, who clicks on it while logged into their banking website. Without the user's knowledge, the link triggers a money transfer from the user's account to the attacker's account. In another scenario, a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link while logged into their social media account, resulting in unauthorized posts being made on their behalf.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Improper management of environment variables
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unsecured and improperly managed environment variables can result in exposure of sensitive data such as API keys and passwords.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers exploiting misconfigurations in environment variables, accessing unsecured storage locations, or intercepting insecurely transmitted data.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, leading to data breaches, financial loss, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an AWS Amplify environment due to poorly secured credentials stored in environment variables and extracts API keys used to access critical backend services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

component.name: AWS CDK (Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment Stack)

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-356
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-356: Product UI does not Warn User of Unsafe Actions The product's user interface does not warn the user before undertaking an unsafe action on behalf of that user. This makes it easier for attackers to trick users into inflicting damage to their system. Product systems should warn users that a potentially dangerous action may occur if the user proceeds. For example, if the user downloads a file from an unknown source and attempts to execute the file on their machine, then the application's GUI can indicate that the file is unsafe.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-696
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-696: Incorrect Behavior Order The product performs multiple related behaviors, but the behaviors are performed in the wrong order in ways which may produce resultant weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

countermeasure.name: Adopt automated secure deployment pipelines for Concourse
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation for best practices on deploying secure, automated pipelines and avoiding insecure methods like manual FTP deployments.

Implement Automated Deployment Pipelines:

  • Develop CI/CD pipelines that automate the build, test, and deployment processes for Concourse, ensuring consistency and reducing human error.
  • Integrate security scanning, code signing, and vulnerability assessments into the pipeline to verify that only secure, verified artifacts are deployed.
  • Avoid manual deployment methods (e.g., FTP) that lack proper encryption and access control, replacing them with automated tools that support secure protocols.

Test and Validate:

  • Deploy test scenarios in a staging environment to ensure that the automated pipelines function as expected and enforce security controls effectively.
  • Validate that deployment logs capture all actions and that any deviations trigger alerts for further investigation.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate deployment logs and metrics with centralized monitoring systems to continuously audit the deployment process.
  • Schedule periodic reviews of the CI/CD pipeline to ensure that it remains secure and compliant with organizational policies.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • Concourse CI Documentation

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools
SA-8 Security and Privacy Engineering Principles

countermeasure.name: Configure Concourse Swift resource with robust authentication integration
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation and the OpenStack Keystone Documentation for detailed guidance on integrating authentication mechanisms.

Integrate Robust Authentication:

  • Update the Concourse Swift resource configuration to integrate with Keystone or another robust authentication service.
  • Specify the appropriate Keystone endpoints and credentials in the configuration files so that all API requests and data exchanges are authenticated.
  • Disable any default or fallback authentication methods to ensure that only requests validated through the robust mechanism are processed.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform tests using both authorized and unauthorized accounts to verify that the authentication integration effectively restricts access to the Swift resource.
  • Monitor authentication logs to ensure that only valid credentials result in access, and that failed attempts are properly logged.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Continuously monitor the authentication logs and integrate them into your centralized logging or SIEM system to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts.
  • Periodically review and update the authentication configuration to maintain alignment with evolving security standards and best practices.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • OpenStack Keystone Documentation

standard.ref: PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Configure latest HTTP protocols for Concourse Swift resource
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation for detailed guidance on implementing the latest HTTP protocols for enhanced security and performance.

Update HTTP Protocol Configuration:

  • Update the configuration settings for the Concourse Swift resource to support the latest HTTP protocols (such as HTTP/2 or HTTP/3, if available) for data transfers and API communications.
  • Ensure that the server and client configurations are aligned to enforce protocol upgrades, optimizing both security and performance.

Test and Validate:

  • Use network analysis tools (e.g., Wireshark) and HTTP protocol testing utilities to confirm that the latest HTTP protocol is being used for all communications.
  • Validate that the configuration changes result in improved performance and do not introduce compatibility issues with existing systems.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate protocol monitoring into your centralized logging system to continuously verify that all communications are utilizing the enhanced HTTP protocol.
  • Periodically review the HTTP configurations and update them as needed to keep pace with evolving security standards and performance improvements.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • Mozilla Developer Network on HTTP/2

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Ensure Keystone integration for Concourse Swift resource
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation for detailed guidance on integrating with Keystone for centralized identity management and access control.

Integrate Keystone Authentication:

  • Update the Concourse Swift resource configuration to include Keystone endpoints and credentials, ensuring that all API interactions are authenticated via Keystone.
  • Configure role-based access control (RBAC) so that only users with valid Keystone tokens and appropriate roles can access and manipulate the Swift resource.
  • Ensure that any defaults or fallback authentication mechanisms are disabled to enforce centralized identity management.

Test and Validate:

  • Perform tests using both authorized and unauthorized accounts to verify that access is properly restricted according to your Keystone policies.
  • Monitor authentication logs to ensure that only valid Keystone-authenticated requests are processed by the Swift resource.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate authentication and access logs into your centralized monitoring or SIEM system to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts.
  • Periodically review the Keystone integration configuration to ensure it remains compliant with evolving security standards and organizational policies.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • OpenStack Keystone Documentation

countermeasure.name: Force HTTPS for Concourse-to-Swift communications
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation for best practices on securing communications between Concourse and Swift.

Configure HTTPS Enforcement:

  • Update the Concourse Swift resource configuration to require HTTPS for all API calls and data transfers.
  • Ensure that both Concourse and Swift endpoints are configured with valid SSL/TLS certificates.
  • Disable any fallback to non-encrypted protocols to guarantee that all traffic is encrypted in transit.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that all communications between Concourse and Swift are transmitted over HTTPS by using network analysis tools (e.g., Wireshark) or SSL testing utilities.
  • Confirm that attempts to connect via HTTP are either automatically redirected to HTTPS or rejected.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate monitoring tools to continuously inspect network traffic for compliance with HTTPS enforcement.
  • Periodically review and update the TLS configurations and certificates to maintain robust encryption standards.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • Mozilla Developer Network on TLS

countermeasure.name: Maintain latest runtime environment for Concourse Swift resource
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation for detailed guidance on updating and maintaining the runtime environment.

Implement Regular Updates:

  • Establish a routine to regularly check for updates to the runtime environment used by the Concourse Swift resource.
  • Schedule automated update processes where possible to deploy the latest stable versions of software components, libraries, and dependencies.
  • Test updates in a staging environment to ensure compatibility and stability before rolling them out to production.

Test and Validate:

  • Validate that updates are applied correctly by monitoring system logs and verifying version numbers after each update cycle.
  • Perform regression tests to ensure that the updated environment does not impact the resources functionality.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate update tracking into your centralized monitoring system to ensure that no components remain outdated.
  • Periodically review the update process and runtime environment configurations to address any vulnerabilities or compatibility issues promptly.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • Concourse CI Documentation

countermeasure.name: Store secrets in a secure vault for Concourse
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps:

Review Documentation:
Consult the Concourse Swift Resource Documentation for guidance on best practices for secure secrets management.

Implement Secure Vault Integration:

  • Deploy a dedicated secrets management solution (e.g., HashiCorp Vault or OpenStack Barbican) to securely store and manage AWX or Concourse secrets.
  • Update Concourse configuration to retrieve secrets securely from the vault instead of embedding them in plaintext configuration files.

Test and Validate:

  • Verify that the secrets are properly encrypted at rest and that only authorized users and services can access them.
  • Perform integration tests to ensure that Concourse successfully retrieves and utilizes the secrets from the secure vault.

Monitor and Audit Regularly:

  • Integrate vault access logs with your centralized monitoring system to track and alert on unauthorized access attempts.
  • Periodically audit the vault configuration and access controls to ensure ongoing compliance with security policies.

References:

  • Concourse Swift Resource Documentation
  • HashiCorp Vault Documentation

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Insecure identity integration
threat.desc:
General threat description

Concourse CI integrates with identity providers like GitHub, LDAP, and OAuth for user authentication. If identity integration is misconfiguredsuch as trusting unvalidated tokens, misassigning roles, or relying on insecure headersattackers may gain unauthorized access to pipelines, secrets, or CI infrastructure.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers exploiting misconfigured OAuth or SSO flows.
  • Insiders abusing overly permissive role mappings.
  • MitM attackers injecting headers or replaying unverified tokens.
  • Malicious users impersonating trusted identities via untrusted proxies.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to pipeline configurations, secrets, and credentials.
  • Compromise of build processes or sensitive deployment targets.
  • Privilege escalation within the CI environment.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Concourse trusts X-Forwarded-User headers from a proxy without validation, allowing impersonation.
  2. OAuth integration lacks scope verification, granting access to users outside the intended organization.
  3. Improper team role mappings give read/write access to unauthorized users.
  4. Expired token reuse allowed due to missing token expiration checks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inefficient web protocols
threat.desc:
General threat description

Concourse uses web-based UIs and APIs to manage CI/CD pipelines. If it relies on outdated or inefficient protocolssuch as HTTP/1.0, uncompressed responses, or lack of connection reuseit can lead to high resource consumption, slower performance, and increased susceptibility to DoS-like conditions under load.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Automated tools or users generating high-frequency requests without keep-alive or compression.
  • Attackers intentionally crafting inefficient connections to degrade performance.
  • CI agents misconfigured to repeatedly reconnect or pull logs inefficiently.

Impacts

  • Increased CPU, memory, and bandwidth usage.
  • Slower UI/API performance and response times.
  • Potential denial of service due to resource exhaustion.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Multiple clients open many short-lived HTTP/1.0 connections, exhausting web process threads.
  2. Concourse API serves logs without gzip compression, leading to high bandwidth usage.
  3. Poorly configured workers constantly poll the web node, spiking resource load.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Insecure management of secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description

Concourse uses secretssuch as credentials, API tokens, and private keysfor pipeline operations. If these are stored insecurely (e.g., in plaintext files, environment variables, or poorly scoped credentials), they can be exposed to unauthorized users or compromised during job execution.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Pipeline authors or insiders embedding secrets directly in pipeline YAML files.
  • Attackers accessing exposed secrets via the UI, logs, or environment variables.
  • Misconfigured secret backends (e.g., Vault, AWS SSM) exposing data due to overly broad access.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to external services, infrastructure, or deployment targets.
  • Compromise of sensitive data and automation workflows.
  • Lateral movement through exposed credentials.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Secrets stored directly in pipeline YAML are visible to all team members or through version control.
  2. Vault integration misconfigured, granting access to secrets beyond the job scope.
  3. Pipeline logs expose sensitive tokens passed via environment variables.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description

Concourse communicates over the network between its web UI, workers, and external systems (e.g., Git, cloud APIs). If these transmissions are not encryptedusing plain HTTP, unencrypted TCP, or non-TLS APIsattackers can intercept sensitive data, including secrets, credentials, and build artifacts.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Network-based attackers sniffing traffic between Concourse components.
  • Man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks on unencrypted API or webhook traffic.
  • Misconfigured deployments using HTTP instead of HTTPS for the web interface or external services.

Impacts

  • Exposure of credentials, tokens, and build metadata.
  • Compromise of pipeline integrity or user accounts.
  • Violation of compliance and data protection standards.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Concourse web UI served over HTTP, exposing login credentials to sniffers.
  2. Worker pulls resources from an unencrypted Git endpoint, exposing code or secrets.
  3. Callback from external service to an unencrypted webhook, allowing injection or interception.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Inadequate authentication controls
threat.desc:
General threat description

Concourse provides a web UI and API to manage pipelines, workers, and credentials. If authentication controls are weaksuch as missing MFA, improper team isolation, or overly broad access via identity providersunauthorized users may gain access to sensitive resources or pipelines.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers exploiting default or weak authentication mechanisms.
  • Misconfigured OAuth/LDAP integrations granting access to unintended users.
  • Compromised user tokens reused due to lack of expiration or revocation.
  • Insiders leveraging shared accounts or team misassignments.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to pipeline definitions, secrets, and job output.
  • Manipulation or disruption of build and deployment workflows.
  • Potential compromise of downstream systems and credentials.

Example attack scenarios

  1. OAuth integration allows any org member to access sensitive pipelines without role filtering.
  2. No MFA enforcement, allowing access with leaked credentials.
  3. Shared team credentials reused across users, bypassing accountability and RBAC.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure deployment practices
threat.desc:
General threat description

Improper deployment of Concoursesuch as exposing components publicly, using default credentials, or skipping security hardeningcan lead to unauthorized access, compromise of CI/CD workflows, and leakage of sensitive data or credentials.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • External attackers scanning for misconfigured or exposed Concourse instances.
  • Insiders or CI/CD operators deploying with weak security defaults.
  • Automation scripts using outdated or insecure deployment templates.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized control over pipelines and workers.
  • Exposure of secrets, tokens, and build artifacts.
  • Service disruption or infrastructure compromise.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Concourse deployed with default admin credentials, allowing anyone to access and modify pipelines.
  2. Web and worker nodes exposed to the internet, enabling direct access to internal services.
  3. CI/CD automation uses outdated containers, introducing known vulnerabilities at runtime.

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General threat description

Concourse pipelines rely on containers and task images to execute builds and deployments. If these runtimessuch as base images, OS packages, or language runtimesare outdated, they may contain known vulnerabilities that can be exploited to compromise the CI/CD environment or downstream infrastructure.

Threat agents / Attack vectors

  • Attackers exploiting known CVEs in outdated images or dependencies.
  • Malicious containers or tasks leveraging old runtimes to escape isolation.
  • CI jobs using deprecated toolchains vulnerable to injection or escalation.

Impacts

  • Remote code execution or data theft within pipeline containers.
  • Compromise of build artifacts or secrets.
  • Spread of vulnerable code or images into production.

Example attack scenarios

  1. Task runs in a container with a known OpenSSL vulnerability, exposing secrets during execution.
  2. Outdated base image lacks patched kernel modules, enabling privilege escalation.
  3. Legacy CI tool in a task image is exploited through crafted pipeline inputs.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1554 - Compromise Host Software Binary

weakness.name: CWE-1190
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1190: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

weakness.name: CWE-184
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-184: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses. Developers often try to protect their products against malicious input by performing tests against inputs that are known to be bad, such as special characters that can invoke new commands. However, such lists often only account for the most well-known bad inputs. Attackers may be able to find other malicious inputs that were not expected by the developer, allowing them to bypass the intended protection mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Deploy CodeBuild projects within a VPC for network isolation
countermeasure.desc: Deploy AWS CodeBuild projects within a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) to ensure that build environments are isolated from external networks, thereby reducing exposure to external threats. Configure your VPC with appropriate security groups and network access control lists (ACLs) to control inbound and outbound traffic to the build environments. This setup ensures that only authorized internal resources can communicate with the CodeBuild environment, enhancing the security of the build process. Additionally, leverage VPC endpoints for secure access to AWS services without traversing the public internet. Implementing this control helps safeguard your build environments against unauthorized access and network-based attacks.

reference.name: Use AWS CodeBuild with Amazon Virtual Private Cloud

countermeasure.name: Encrypt build artifacts at rest in S3
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all build artifacts generated by AWS CodeBuild are stored in Amazon S3 with encryption enabled at rest. This prevents unauthorized access to sensitive data by protecting the artifacts using AWS-managed encryption keys (SSE-S3) or customer-managed keys (SSE-KMS). To implement this control, configure the S3 bucket that stores your build artifacts to enable server-side encryption (SSE) by default. Review and validate that all existing and new artifacts are encrypted at rest. This practice helps maintain the confidentiality and integrity of your build outputs, mitigating the risk of data breaches.

reference.name: Data encryption

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enforce strict input validation in build scripts
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict validation of all inputs used within AWS CodeBuild scripts to prevent code injection attacks. Ensure that any parameters, environment variables, or external data consumed by build scripts are thoroughly validated for correctness, format, and security. Incorporate validation checks within the build scripts to sanitize inputs, rejecting any malformed or potentially malicious data before it is processed. Use allowlists, regular expressions, and secure coding practices to further reduce the risk of injection vulnerabilities. This control helps maintain the integrity and security of your build process by preventing unauthorized code execution.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Regularly update build environments with latest patches and software versions
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all AWS CodeBuild environments are consistently updated with the latest security patches and software versions. This includes regularly reviewing and applying updates to the underlying operating systems, libraries, and dependencies used within your build environments. Automate the update process where possible by utilizing AWS services such as AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager or incorporating patching steps into your CI/CD pipeline. Regularly verify that your build environments are up-to-date to minimize vulnerabilities and protect against potential security threats. Maintaining current software versions is critical for the security and stability of your build processes.

reference.name: Docker images provided by CodeBuild

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to S3 buckets for build artifacts
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that access to S3 buckets storing AWS CodeBuild artifacts is tightly controlled by implementing strict permissions. Configure bucket policies and IAM roles to allow access only to authorized users and services that require it. Utilize the principle of least privilege by granting the minimum necessary permissions for accessing, modifying, or managing the build artifacts. Additionally, consider enabling logging and monitoring of access to these S3 buckets using AWS CloudTrail and Amazon S3 access logs to detect any unauthorized access attempts. Proper access control ensures the confidentiality and integrity of your build artifacts.

reference.name: Security in AWS CodeBuild

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Sanitize build logs to remove sensitive data
countermeasure.desc: Implement log sanitization processes within AWS CodeBuild to ensure that any sensitive data, such as credentials, API keys, or personally identifiable information (PII), is removed or obfuscated before logs are stored or shared. This can be achieved by incorporating log filtering mechanisms in your build scripts or using custom logging configurations that exclude sensitive information. Regularly audit and review build logs to identify and address any inadvertent exposure of sensitive data. By sanitizing logs, you protect sensitive information from unauthorized access and reduce the risk of data leakage.

reference.name: Help protect sensitive log data with masking

countermeasure.name: Use approved and hardened build images
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that only approved and security-hardened build images are used in AWS CodeBuild projects. Maintain a curated list of build images that have been vetted for security vulnerabilities and are configured according to your organization's security standards. Regularly update these images to include the latest security patches and remove outdated or vulnerable ones. Enforce the use of these approved images by restricting the selection of build environments in your CodeBuild project configurations. This control helps minimize the risk of executing malicious scripts and enhances the overall security of your build process.
